Landscapes: Land Cover Patterns

Author

2022-02-13

Source: vignettes/more/landscapes-landcover-patterns.Rmd
landscapes-landcover-patterns.Rmd
  • sen2r get data & classify (Otsu’s thresholding)
  • Include DTM/DSM processing to convert to turf/shrub/canopy?
  • landscapemetrics

To make sense of the raster data, the important information (e.g. landscape metrics) has to be isolated from the noise. Otsu’s thresholding (Otsu, 1979) is an automated threshold finder that outperforms other techniques in terms of stability of results and processing speed, even with the presence of >2 peaks in the histogram (Bouhennache et al., 2019). The NDVI threshold for vegetation typically ranges from 0.2 to 0.4 (Wong et al, 2019; Akbar et al, 2019). Setting a threshold value for each index allows for the assignment of pixels with the absence or presence of the respective land cover type, which facilitates the classification of raster files.

veg_classified <- data(mosaic)

# get threshold value via otsu method (assumes bimodal histogram)
threshold <- list()
for(i in 1:length(rounds)){
  thresholds[[i]] <- threshold_otsu(veg_classified[i], levels = 256) #default levels = 256 for 8-bit images
  rm(i)
}

# view thresholds
thresholds[[1]]
#[value 1]

Distribution of NDVI values across Singapore in Survey Round One (light green bars, dashed vertical lines) and Two (dark green bars, solid vertical lines). Based on image mosaic composed of data captured for Survey Round One and Survey Round Two. Vegetation was classified as pixel with values >0.35 for Round One and >0.36 for Round Two, via Otsu’s thresholding. Dense vegetation was classified as pixels with values >0.62 for Round One and >0.64 for Round Two, using the same method after the first round of classification.
